units.title: Integrate single-cell transcriptomics and Visium data
units.text: After integrating single-cell transcriptomics and Visium data using our recently developed cell2location algorithm18, cell states were mapped to the endometrium and/or the myometrium.
units.rationale: This is an actionable computational step that defines a protocol for spatial mapping of cell states using specific tools and data types.

units.title: Classify epithelial cells into four main groups
units.text: Epithelial cells are classified into four main groups based on their marker expression: (1) SOX9 populations, enriched in the proliferative phase and expressing genes characteristic of rising estrogen levels (MMP7, ESR1); (2) ciliated cells (PIFO, TPPP3); (3) lumenal cells (LGR5); and (4) glandular cells (SCGB2A2) (Fig. 2b–d and Extended Data Fig. 4a,b).
units.rationale: This provides a clear, marker-based classification protocol for epithelial cell subtypes with defined gene signatures.

units.title: Define spatial coordinates of SOX9 subsets using integrated data
units.text: By integrating scRNA-seq and Visium data (Fig. 2e and Extended Data Fig. 4c), we define specific spatial coordinates for these SOX9 subsets: (1) noncycling SOX9+LGR5+ cells are enriched in the surface epithelium; (2) noncycling SOX9+LGR5− cells are located in the basal glands; and (3) cycling SOX9+ cells map to glands in the regenerating superficial layer.
units.rationale: This is a protocol step for assigning spatial localization to cell subtypes using integrated transcriptomic and spatial data.

units.title: Validate marker expression with smFISH and RNAscope
units.text: Single-molecule fluorescence in situ hybridization (smFISH) with RNAscope probes shows higher expression of the proliferative marker MKI67 in the superficial layer of the endometrium during the proliferative phase, validating Visium data (Extended Data Fig. 5a).
units.rationale: This describes a validated experimental protocol for confirming spatial gene expression patterns using a specific imaging technique.

units.title: Modulate WNT and NOTCH pathways in organoid cultures
units.text: Finally, by modulating WNT and NOTCH pathways in the organoid cultures, we develop lineage-specific endometrial epithelial cells and define the molecular events involved in their response to ovarian hormones.
units.rationale: This is a direct experimental protocol for manipulating signaling pathways in organoids to induce lineage specification.

units.title: Profile 3D endometrial organoids at single-cell resolution
units.text: We profile three-dimensional endometrial organoids at single-cell resolution to characterize their hormonal responses in vitro and design a computational toolkit to compare the results with those observed in vivo to benchmark this model system.
units.rationale: This outlines a protocol for using 3D organoids to study hormonal responses at single-cell resolution and compare them to in vivo data.

units.title: Identify and annotate cell clusters using known markers
units.text: We identify 14 clusters that were assigned cell identity based on their expression of known markers (Extended Data Fig. 1g).
units.rationale: This is a standard protocol step for annotating cell clusters in scRNA-seq data using established marker genes.

units.title: Subcluster immune cells to resolve heterogeneity
units.text: Subclustering of immune cells resolves their heterogeneity, including identification of the three uterine natural killer cells (uNK1, uNK2, uNK3), dendritic cells (DCs), macrophages (uM1, uM2), and other subsets.
units.rationale: This describes a specific analytical protocol for resolving immune cell diversity through hierarchical clustering and annotation.

units.title: Integrate scRNA-seq data from biopsies and whole tissue samples
units.text: We were able to generate a uterine map of 98,568 cells from 15 individuals by integrating our dataset with previous scRNA-seq data obtained from superficial endometrial biopsies22 (Fig. 1b, Extended Data Fig. 1b–f and Supplementary Table 2).
units.rationale: This is a protocol for combining datasets from different sample types to create a comprehensive cell atlas.

units.title: Use CellPhoneDB v.3.0 to measure intercellular communication with spatial coordinates
units.text: We develop CellPhoneDB v.3.0 to measure intercellular communication taking into account spatial coordinates of cells and use this tool to define cell signaling in both lumenal and glandular epithelial microenvironments.
units.rationale: This describes a protocol for analyzing cell-cell communication by integrating spatial data with a specific computational tool.
